unnormalised: Delhi is facing a concerning rise in cases of dengue fever, with reports indicating a 20% increase in the last 2 weeks alone. Dr. Rajesh Kumar from AIIMS Delhi warned that the current situation could worsen due to the ongoing monsoon season, which provides ideal breeding grounds for mosquitoes. The MCD has initiated fogging drives in several areas, including Karol Bagh and Rohini, but residents complain that these efforts are not enough.
normalised: Delhi is facing a concerning rise in cases of dengue fever, with reports indicating a twenty percent increase in the last two weeks alone. Doctor Rajesh Kumar from A-I-I-M-S Delhi warned that the current situation could worsen due to the ongoing monsoon season, which provides ideal breeding grounds for mosquitoes. The M-C-D has initiated fogging drives in several areas, including Karol Bagh and Rohini, but residents complain that these efforts are not enough.

unnormalised: Symptoms reported by local hospitals include high fever (102-104°F), severe joint pain, and skin rashes. Health officials are advising people to take preventive measures such as using mosquito repellents and wearing full-sleeved clothing. Several pharmacies in the city report a surge in demand for paracetamol and mosquito nets. "We’re seeing almost double the usual number of customers," said Mr. Sharma, a local pharmacist.
normalised: Symptoms reported by local hospitals include high fever (one hundred and two to one hundred and four degree Fahrenheit), severe joint pain, and skin rashes. Health officials are advising people to take preventive measures such as using mosquito repellents and wearing full-sleeved clothing. Several pharmacies in the city report a surge in demand for paracetamol and mosquito nets. "We're seeing almost double the usual number of customers," said Mister Sharma, a local pharmacist.

unnormalised: The government has allocated Rs. 5 crore to combat the spread of dengue and chikungunya. Furthermore, a helpline number (1075) has been activated for citizens to report suspected cases and seek assistance. Health experts are emphasizing the importance of early detection and treatment to prevent complications. Remember to consult a doctor if you experience any symptoms.
normalised: The government has allocated rupees five crore to combat the spread of dengue and chikungunya. Furthermore, a helpline number (one zero seven five) has been activated for citizens to report suspected cases and seek assistance. Health experts are emphasizing the importance of early detection and treatment to prevent complications. Remember to consult a doctor if you experience any symptoms.
